# Inferred pairwise interactions vary widely among models

**Figure S3. Pairwise β-turnover among network reconstruction approaches.**  

The heatmaps summarize differences in inferred pairwise interactions across all model pairs for networks constructed from identical taxon pools. The **left panel** shows the mean β-turnover, where warmer colours indicate higher turnover (fewer shared interactions) and cooler colours indicate greater overlap. The **right panel** shows the standard deviation of β-turnover across replicates, indicating the consistency of differences.  

Models with similar ecological assumptions, such as **ADBM** and **L-matrix**, exhibit low mean turnover and low variability, reflecting consistent inference of shared interactions. In contrast, the **body-size ratio** and **random** models show both high mean turnover and higher variability, indicating inconsistent and divergent pairwise interactions. **PFIM** exhibits intermediate turnover and moderate consistency relative to size-based theoretical models. ## Model choice influences inferred extinction dynamics

**Figure S4. Temporal trajectories of network-level metrics across reconstruction models.**  

Macro (connectance, trophic level), Meso (motif counts: linear chains, omnivory, direct and apparent competition), and Micro (generality, vulnerability). Lines represent mean values across replicates. Deterministic, size-based models (ADBM, L-matrix) show highly similar trajectories, whereas stochastic or trait-driven models (log ratio, niche, random) exhibit greater divergence in both mean values and temporal patterns, consistent with GAM analyses (see main text).
